sentence-detokenized: The EU rejects Germany's call for a boycott of British lamb.
Peter Blackburn
BRIUSEL 22-08-1996

On Thursday, the European Commission said it does not support Germany's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb until scientists have established whether mad cow disease can be transmitted to sheep.

Germany's representative on the European Union's veterinary committee, Werner Zwingmann, said on Wednesday that consumers should buy sheepmeat from countries other than Britain until scientific advice is clearer.
"We do not support any such recommendation because we do not see any justification for it," said the Commission's chief spokesman Nikolaus van der Pas.
He said that further research was needed and that if action was needed, it should be taken by the European Union.

He said that last month's proposal by EU Agriculture Commissioner Fischler to ban sheep brain, spleen and spinal cord from the human and animal food chain is a very concrete and cautious step to protect human health.
Following reports in the UK and France that sheep could be infected with BSE - mad cow disease - under laboratory conditions, Fischler proposed EU-wide measures.

However, Fischler agreed to revise his proposal after the EU's Standing Veterinary Committee and national animal health officials questioned whether such an action was justified, given the low risk to human health.
Earlier at a meeting of EU agriculture ministers, Spain's agriculture minister Loyola de Palacio accused Fischler of raising unjustified concerns about a "dangerous generalisation".
Fischler's proposal was supported only by France and Great Britain.
The EU's Scientific Veterinary and Multidisciplinary Committees are due to re-examine the issue early next month and make recommendations to senior veterinary officials.
It has long been known that sheep can be infected with scrapie, a brain-destroying disease similar to BSE, which is thought to have been transmitted to cattle in feed containing animal waste.

On Thursday, British farmers denied that their sheep pose a risk to human health, but expressed concern that the German government's advice to consumers to avoid British lamb could affect consumers across Europe.
"We need to be very careful about how other countries take up the German example," John Lloyd Jones, President of the National Farmers' Union of Wales (NFU), told BBC Radio Wales.

Efforts have been made in Bonn to protect public health after consumer confidence plummeted in March after a British report suggested that people eating contaminated beef could contract a disease similar to mad cow disease.
Last year, Germany imported 47,600 sheep from the UK, almost half of its total imports.
Sheepmeat imports from Great Britain amounted to 4275 tonnes, around 10% of total imports.
A rare draft of a Hendrix song sells for nearly $17,000.
A rare early draft of a handwritten song by US guitar legend Jimi Hendrix was sold on Thursday for nearly 17 000 US dollars at an auction of some of the late musician's favourite items.
A Florida restaurant paid £10,925 (USD 16,935) for a draft of "Ain't no telling", which Hendrix wrote on a piece of London hotel stationery in late 1966.
At the end of a concert in Nottingham, England, in January 1967, he threw a piece of paper into the audience, where it was pulled out by a fan.
The buyers also acquired 16 other items consigned to the auction by Hendrix's ex-girlfriend Kathy Etchingham, who lived with him from 1966 to 1969.
Among them was a black lacquer and mother-of-pearl-encrusted box used by Hendrix to store drugs, bought by an anonymous buyer from Australia for £5060 ($7845).
The guitarist died of a drug overdose in 1970, aged 27.
China claims that Taiwan is spoiling the negotiating atmosphere.
BEIJING 22-08-1996

On Thursday, China accused Taipei of spoiling the atmosphere for talks on the resumption of the Taiwan Strait by Taiwanese Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Ukraine this week, which angered Beijing.

Just hours after Chinese state media said it was time to start political talks with Taiwan, foreign ministry spokesman Shen Guofang told Reuters "the Taiwanese government has disrupted the atmosphere necessary for the start of the talks".
State media quoted China's chief negotiator with Taipei, Tang Shubei, as telling a visiting Taiwanese group on Wednesday that the time had come for the rivals to enter into political talks.
"Now is the time for both sides to start political negotiations...
is to end hostilities," Tang was quoted as saying by Thursday's People's Daily, a foreign publication.

Foreign ministry spokesman Shen told Reuters in an interview that he had read reports of Tang's comments, but gave no details on why the negotiator thought the time was right for talks with Taiwan, which is considered by Beijing to be a breakaway province.
China, which has long opposed all efforts by Taipei to gain greater international recognition, was angered by this week's visit by Taiwan's Vice President Lien to Ukraine.
China says it's time to negotiate on Taiwan.
BEIJING 22-08-1996
China has said that the time has come to enter into political negotiations with Taiwan and that the rival island should take practical steps to achieve this.

Late on Wednesday, the official Xinhua news agency quoted Tang Shubei, executive vice-chairman of the Taiwan Straits Relations Association, as saying that consultations should be held on the timing and format of the talks.
Car registrations in Germany rose by 14.2% year-on-year in July.
FRANKFURT 1996-08-22
The number of motor vehicles registered for the first time in Germany in July this year increased by 14.2% compared to July last year, the Federal Motor Vehicle Office said on Thursday.
The Office stated that 356 725 new cars were registered in July 1996 - 304 850 cars and 15 613 trucks.
Compared to July 1995, the number of passenger cars increased by 13.6% and the number of trucks decreased by 2.2%.
Motorcycle registrations increased by 32.7% during this period.
The increase was partly due to more Germans buying German cars abroad, while manufacturers said domestic demand was weak, the federal office said.
Almost all German car manufacturers saw an increase in registrations during this period.
"Volkswagen AG received 77,719 registrations, just over a quarter of all registrations.
Opel AG and General Motors came second with 49,269 registrations, 16.4% of the total.
Ford came third with 35,563 registrations, or 11.7%.
Only Seat and Porsche registered fewer cars in July 1996 compared to July last year.
"Seat registered 3,420 registrations compared to 5,522 a year earlier in July.
"Porsche registrations fell from 643 to 554.
THE GREEK SOCIALISTS HAVE GIVEN THE GREEN LIGHT FOR THE PRIME MINISTERIAL ELECTIONS.
The Greek Socialist Party's Executive Bureau has authorised Prime Minister Kostas Simitis to call early elections, its Secretary General Costas Skandalidis told reporters.
Prime Minister Costas Simitis intends to make an official announcement after a cabinet meeting later on Thursday, said Mr Skandalidis.
-- Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens News Service +301 3311812-4

Israel downplays the fear of war with Syria.
Colleen Siegel
JERUZALE 1996-08-22
On Thursday, Israel's outgoing peace negotiator with Syria said that the current tensions between the two countries look like a storm in a teacup.
Itamar Rabinovich, who led the failed negotiations with Syria as Israel's ambassador in Washington, told Israel Radio that Damascus seems to want to talk rather than fight.
"It seems to me that {(1)[MISC] Syria's priority} is still negotiations.
The Syrians are confused, they are certainly stressed, but the general assessment here in Washington is that this is basically a storm in a teacup", he said.
Rabinovic completes his term as ambassador.
He will be replaced by Eliahu Ben-Elissar, former Israeli envoy to Egypt and politician from the right-wing Likud party.
On Wednesday, Israel sent a message to Syria via Washington that it is committed to peace and is willing to start negotiations without preconditions.
However, she criticised Damascus for creating what she called a dangerous atmosphere.
On Wednesday, Syria accused Israel of launching a hysterical campaign against it after Israeli TV reported that Damascus had recently tested a missile.
She claimed that she bought the weapons for defence purposes.

"We have sent a message to Syrian President Hafez al-Assad that Israel is ready to start peace talks at any time and without any preconditions," Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy said in an interview with Israel Radio.
Tensions have risen since Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who took office in June, pledged to keep the Golan Heights, which Israel seized from Syria in the 1967 Middle East war.
Israeli-Syrian peace talks on the Golan have been stalled since 1991, despite the previous government's willingness to make concessions on the Golan.
The last peace talks between the two sides took place in February.
"The voices coming out of Damascus are bad, not good.
Media...
there are many expressions and declarations that must be worrying...
This artificial atmosphere is very dangerous because those who spread it can become its prisoners," said Levy.
"We hope that Syria, if it has its face turned towards peace, will respond to Israel's call for peace talks, because that is our goal", he said. "
We do not want war, God forbid.
Wars are good for no one. "
Israel's Channel Two television said Damascus had sent a "wake-up call" to Israel.
It did not provide any source for the report.
B. Netanyahu and B. Levy's representatives said they could not confirm this.
The TV station also claimed that Netanyahu had sent messages to reassure Syria via Cairo, the United States and Moscow.
A Polish diplomat denies that nurses are trapped in Libya.
On Thursday, a Polish diplomat denied a report in a Polish tabloid this week that Libya is refusing exit visas to 100 Polish nurses trying to return home after working in the North African country.
"This is not true.

To date, we are not aware of any nurses trapped in Libya or being held without their will, and we have not received any complaints," Tadeusz Awdankiewicz, Chargé d'Affaires at the Polish Embassy in Tripoli, told Reuters by phone.

The Polish labour ministry announced this week that it would send a team to Libya to investigate, but Mr Awdankiewicz said the investigation was prompted by complaints from some nurses about their working conditions, such as unpaid wages.
He said there are around 800 Polish nurses working in Libya.
Two Iranian opposition leaders meet in Baghdad.
Hassan Hafidh
BAGHDAD 1996-08-22
An Iraq-based group of Iranian exiles pledged on Thursday to provide support to Iranian Kurdish rebels after they were attacked by Iranian troops last month inside Iraq.

"Mujahideen Khalq said in a statement that its leader, Massoud Rajavi, had met the Secretary General of the Kurdistan Democratic Party of Iran (KDPI), Hassan Rastegar, on Wednesday in Baghdad and expressed his support for the Iranian Kurdish insurgency.
"Rajavi stressed that the Iranian Resistance Movement will continue to stand side by side with its Kurdish compatriots and the Resistance Movement in Iranian Kurdistan," the statement said.
A spokesman for the group said that the meeting "represents a new level of cooperation between Mujahideen Khalq and the Iranian Kurdish opposition".
In July, Iran intensively bombed targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of KDPI guerrillas based in Iraqi Kurdish areas not under the control of the government in Baghdad.
Iraqi Kurdish areas bordering Iran are controlled by guerrillas from the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan (PUK) group of Iraqi Kurds.
The PUK and the Iraqi Kurdistan Democratic Party (KDP), the two main factions of Iraqi Kurds, have controlled northern Iraq since Iraqi forces were driven out of Kuwait in the 1991 Gulf War.
Over the weekend, the two parties clashed in the most serious clashes since the US-backed ceasefire last year.
"Mujahideen Khalq said that Iranian troops had also shelled KDP positions in the Qasri region of Suleimaniyah province near the Iranian border over the past two days.
It said that around 100 Iraqi Kurds were killed or injured in the attack.
Both Iran and Turkey are conducting air and ground strikes against targets in northern Iraq in pursuit of their Kurdish rebels.
The US-led air force in southern Turkey protects Iraqi Kurds from possible attacks by Baghdad troops.
The Saudi riyal remains unchanged in the quiet summer trade.
The spot Saudi riyal exchange rate against the dollar and riyal interbank deposit rates were broadly stable this week amid quiet summer trading, dealers in the Kingdom said.
"The Saudi riyal has remained unchanged.
The market was very calm because of the summer holidays", said one trader.
The spot rate for the riyal was 3,7504/06 per US dollar.
One-month interbank deposits were 5-1/2, 3/8%, three-month 5-5/8, 1/2% and six-month 5-3/4, 5/8%.
One-year funds accounted for 6.5-7/8% of the total.
Israel supports Arafat's flight to the West Bank.
JERUZALE 1996-08-22
Israel allowed Palestinian President Yasser Arafat to fly over its territory into the West Bank on Thursday, ending a brief crisis between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, an Arafat aide said.
"The problem is over.
The President's plane has been cleared to fly through Israeli airspace, but the President is not expected to arrive in the West Bank before Monday," Nabil Abu Rdainah told Reuters.

Arafat was due to meet former Israeli Prime Minister Shimon Peres in the West Bank city of Ramallah on Thursday, but the venue was changed to Gaza after Israel refused to allow the Palestinian leader's helicopters to fly.
Palestinian officials accused right-wing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of trying to stop the Ramallah meeting by preventing Arafat from leaving.
Later, Arafat cancelled a meeting between Israeli and PLO officials on civil matters at the Allenby Bridge between Jordan and the West Bank.
Abu Rdainah said that Arafat decided not to fly to the West Bank on Thursday, when Israel lifted the ban, because he had a busy schedule in Gaza and would not be free until Monday.
Arafat will meet Peres in Gaza after the flight ban.
JERUZALE 1996-08-22

Yasser Arafat will meet Shimon Peres on Thursday in the Gaza Strip after the Palestinians claimed that the right-wing Israeli government had prevented the Palestinian leader from flying to the West Bank to hold talks with the former Prime Minister.

On Wednesday, Japanese Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said at a press conference that he believes that the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) interest rate policy, which is aimed at securing economic growth, has not changed following the publication of the central bank's "tankan" survey.
